column1: #Text=maybe , but printed books too and they do not get corrected .
#Text=It is also totally unrealistic to compare the Wikipedia with a work like the Britannica ( for which you need a subscription because we have no micropayments ) .
#Text=One should compare the Wikipedia with what people have in their homes ( often NOTHING ! ) or in their heads .
#Text=If the Wikipedia is as good as the Brittanica , then hats off !
#Text=Are wikis viable in the longer term ?
#Text=I think so .
#Text=They give authors a frame to work in .
#Text=Whatever comes later , that frame is important .
#Text=You 've edited your own article on Wikipedia , did you find it easy to work with ?
#Text=You probably do n't have a lot of experience with it , but what is your impression of the MediaWiki software that Wikipedia runs on ?
#Text=I find it very good .
#Text=Precisely because I do not use it often
#Text=it is important that it is sufficiently simple and intuitive that I do not need a manual .
#Text=The wiki software fulfills this criterion and is therefore very good : the frame is important . !
#Text=Will it be possible to agree on common standards , with the software companies trying to push their own standards ?
#Text=Are there major obstacles for XML ?
#Text=We can apparently agree on common standards : OS X is full of XML and even Microsoft now uses XML for its Office products .
#Text=Proprietary standards are not bad in themselves .
#Text=They let one try out new things or be efficient in some ways .

#Text=I do not object to them on one condition : that there is a way to export all data in an XML form , with all the details I could control through the application transmitted to the XML in recognisable form .
#Text=The W3 Consortium succeeded in spreading the WWW standards and did even more : several commercial standards converged under its influence .
#Text=That is the good news .
#Text=Lawmakers are lagging behind when it comes to computer- and information-technology .
#Text=On your site , you say : In a society based on technology it is simply dangerous to make policy on the basis of language constructs only .
#Text=What is the alternative to language-based policy ?
#Text=A few years ago I had to speak about www at the European Parliament in Brussels .
#Text=I was shocked that there was no way to use anything else than spoken language .
#Text=No screen , no projector , no whiteboard .
#Text=How can one say anything sensible about climate change without showing maps , graphs , videos ?
#Text=But perhaps we should first work on the scientific literacy of our politicians .
#Text=Maybe that wo n't be necessary if the next form of government grows from web 2.0 .
#Text=I just discovered Newropeans ( http://www.newropeans.org ) .
#Text=Who knows .
#Text=The old technology of the spoken language alone certainly no longer works .
